issue.title: Why are validation shown against value rather than field name?
LaunchMeteor.exe leads to "Please press any key to exit" then closes window.
issue.body:
Full output:

```
run: You're not in a Meteor project directory.

To create a new Meteor project:
   meteor create <project name>
For example:
   meteor create myapp

For more help, see 'meteor --help'.

Please press any key to exit.
```

First time it installed correctly and after all progress bars it displayed the same message above.

I'm using Windows 8.1 Build 9431. 

What can I do? 

Thanks!

issue.title: LaunchMeteor.exe leads to "Please press any key to exit" then closes window.
issue.body:
Full output:

```
run: You're not in a Meteor project directory.

To create a new Meteor project:
   meteor create <project name>
For example:
   meteor create myapp

For more help, see 'meteor --help'.

Please press any key to exit.
```

First time it installed correctly and after all progress bars it displayed the same message above.

I'm using Windows 8.1 Build 9431. 

What can I do? 

Thanks!

comment.body:
Quick update: 

I'm a MinGW user and tried to install the traditional Meteor before the Windows version. Installation didn't worked and the installer quitted with a message saying my OS is not supported. I'm not sure if that influenced in the error at first.

After executing LaunchMeteor.exe I've tried typing `meteor` on MinGW, but it is a `command not found`. MinGW knows my PATH so it should work. After some tryouts I've found it works on `cmd.exe`, so I'm closing this. 

I don't know if the error message when running LaunchMeteor.exe is normal, but I believe it shouldn't be. Neither way, I got it working so I'm closing this. Feel free to reopen and request any information you need if you guys think this is something to be fixed.

Thank you!

I'm using Windows 8.1 Build 9431. 

What can I do? 

Thanks!

issue.title: DDP specification document should list valid protocols
issue.body:
The current packages/livedata/DDP.md document tells us:

The client sends a connect message.
If the server is willing to speak the version of the protocol specified in the connect message, it sends back a connected message.

It would be nice if it specified the pattern for the version strings and what the current version is, so we don't have to trawl through the code to find it.

comment.body: Is there any update on this? Spec still seems to be the same as 7 months ago. Can I rely on some version string format?

issue.title: DDP specification document should list valid protocols
issue.body:
The current packages/livedata/DDP.md document tells us:

The client sends a connect message.
If the server is willing to speak the version of the protocol specified in the connect message, it sends back a connected message.

It would be nice if it specified the pattern for the version strings and what the current version is, so we don't have to trawl through the code to find it.

comment.body: I'd like an update on that. It has been 7 months.

issue.title: Less strenuous install procedure?
issue.body:
I would love to use Respect/Validation. All the usage examples make it look spectacular and very intuitive.

But the install seems DESIGNED to exclude adoption. I'm hoping that's just my ignorance; I have to support LOTS of stuff in our little operation, and PHP is just one of the things I have to cope with in a "I know just enough to squeak by" basis. So some of the latest sophisticated PHP refinements are still on my TODO list to learn.

Am I right in understanding the following with respect to Respect/Validation:

1. You can't just unzip and copy the package to your server. You HAVE to use PEAR or Composer whether you like it or not.
2. Given the fact that we use shared hosting on GoDaddy, not wanting to devote our lives to the care and feeding of a web server of our very own, using Composer or PEAR pretty much REQUIRES permissions and PHP command liine access that MANY providers won't give people like us, ensuring we CAN'T use the install mechanisms Respect/Validation REQUIRES us to use.
3. One has to understand, gen up and use a roll-your-own autoloader or understand THAT whole thing well enough to borrow someone else's.

So, while the use of Respect/Validation is gorgeous, elegant and stunningly powerful, it requires a life-style commitment to the PHP priesthood to just GET IT INSTALLED? There will be NO "just stick it in a directory, require_once and go"?

I'd be grateful for a slap-down here, to find out I've misunderstood  the whole thing, and a direction to nice set of simple "unzip and copy" instructions such as normal, fallible humans who don't have the time or resources to re-architect their world for the sake of one PHP library and it's view of how installs SHOULD be done, as peachy as that library may be.

For the time being, in hopeful anticipation of that glorious come-uppance, I'm stuck with GUMP.

I await my beating in happy anticipation. Predicated on the notion that I actually get the answer I need to move forward and not a lot of religious philosophy about what I SHOULD be doing.

comment.body:
We used to have standalone .phar packages, but no one used them. Straight snapshot zip files are available in both GitHub and our pear channel, but they don't include autoloading.

Respect\Validation does not require Composer or PEAR, just a PSR-0 compatible autoloader, like the 20-line snippet that @augustohp posted. There is also the Respect\Loader: http://github.com/Respect/Loader. You can download zips of both Respect\Loader and Respect\Validation side by side without Composer or PEAR, but it would not make sense to "ship" Respect\Loader in each one of the Respect projects, since it can be a separate component. I'm open to suggestions though =)

If you don't want autoloading (by your own or Composer), you can `require_once` classes for yourself, but since Respect is largely modular, it will be lot of requires. Autoloading is a kind of requirement for object-oriented projects, and it's good for both library developers and their users (since your classes can be autoloaded as well).

issue.title: How do you tackle nested wheres
issue.body: things like `where foo=1 and (where bar=0 or baz=0)` ?

comment.body:
Using the `Sql` class as this:

`$this->object->select('*')->from('table')->where($data[0])->and_($data[1])->or($data[2])->_()`

Leads to:

`"SELECT * FROM table WHERE (a = ? OR b = ?) AND (c = ? OR d = ?)"`

That's from our unit tests: https://github.com/Respect/Relational/blob/develop/tests/library/Respect/Relational/SqlTest.php#L294

It is not currently supported on the Mapper though, just `Respect\Relational\Db` and `Respect\Relational\Sql`.

issue.title: Deprecated: preg_replace(): The /e modifier is deprecated
issue.body: `Deprecated: preg_replace(): The /e modifier is deprecated, use preg_replace_callback instead in .../respect/data/library/Respect/Data/Styles/AbstractStyle.php on line 20`

comment.body:
This should be easy to fix. The `/e` modifier is being used to convert camelCase to case_separators and we could do that without regular expressions, or maybe using `preg_replace_callback` instead of `/e`. 

Still, I haven't tested any Respect component in PHP 5.5 yet as @wesleyvicthor noticed. We sure want to make it work.

If you need a quick fix, you can extend any of the `Respect\Data\Styles\` class and replace the `separatorToCamelCase` method on it, then `$mapper->setStyle(new \MyCustomStyleThatExtendsAnotherOne)`. Extended custom styles can also be used to change how table and column naming works. I use them all the time =D

issue.title: Bug when passing a NULL value as ID
issue.body:
Something like:
`$mapper->table[NULL]->fetch();`
will return the first row it can find, not an error or nothing.

comment.body:
I'm not sure what we could do. 

A call to `$mapper->something[NULL]` is equivalent to `$mapper->something->setCondition(null)`, which is roughly the same as setting no condition at all to that collection and therefore Relational thinks that it should target the entire table. In other words, a NULL condition is no condition.

Perhaps we could patch `setCondition` (on Respect\Data\Collections\Collection) to handle the PHP `null` to a `id IS NULL` instruction. Null values on SQL can't be compared with equality operators (by the SQL92 spec, nothing is equal null and every null is different from each other).

What do you think?

issue.title: callable on exception shows an error.
issue.body: When we use a callable that throws an exception we have an error, that occurs because we are running it inside the __toString(); method.
